Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Data Collection of Internal Forces During Dismantling of a Steel Bridge

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Collecting bridge performance data on an existing bridge is useful to understand internal forces that a structure experiences under service condition. A bridge that has provided service for more than eighty years is planned to be dismantled in August 2014. Generally when a bridge is decommissioned it is demolished with explosives for efficiency. However, this steel bridge will be dismantled one piece at a time because of its proximity to the new replacement bridge. This dismantling provides an opportunity to collect data of bridge member forces using sensors and wireless data acquisition system. The data will be used for validating computer simulation algorithm with real field data. The bridge that has been in the service for a long time generally weakens due to deterioration of material and due to loading of traffic. The collected data will help in understanding aging of the bridge. A relatively small amount of investment will provide rich data that will be useful to researchers in modeling life-cycle performance of a typical bridge.

This project will collect field data during dismantling of an old steel truss bridge. The data will be in the form of internal forces in truss members. Strain gages and wireless data acquisition system will be used to collect data of internal forces as the bridge is dismantled piece by piece. Since the bridge has been in use for more than eighty years there has been some deterioration of materials and connections. Detailed data on the existing condition of members and connections will be collected prior to beginning of the dismantling of the bridge. The collected data will be archived for later use by the principal investigator and other researchers to validate current numerical simulation algorithm. There is a potential of assessing uncertainties in modeling aspect of truss bridge structure as well as in environmental deterioration. Preliminary numerical simulation using available software will be pursued to assess efficacy of simulation of a bridge that has been in service.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Force measurements have and are currently being collected during deconstruction of a steel truss bridge. This effort is allowing the research team to advance our understanding with regard to locked-in internal force variation within constructed structural systems. In large-scale structural systems these locked-in forces are substantially greater than typical forces due to service loads. However, the majority of the experimental research has focused on structural behavior due to service loads, as well as extreme events. This is partly due to the fact that experimental techniques are limited with regard to measurement of locked-in internal forces. As a result, numerical models are assumed to accurately capture these forces simply because no other information is available. At the present time, reliable measurement of total locked-in forces can only be measured through construction monitoring or localized nondestructive evaluation techniques. Each approach has merit and provides important information. Deconstruction monitoring is the methodology utilized in this study to further the knowledge base in this research area. Thus far, the primary outcomes of the project include:

  • Experiment Design: A finite element (FE) model was constructed based on the existing data (see attached Image 1). Sensitivity studies were performed for refinement of the experiment design to ensure meaningful data was obtained from the field measurements. An instrumentation plan was developed that included 48 strain gages and 12 data acquisition systems (see attached Image 2).
  • Data Collection: This effort included design and procurement of all necessary sensors and data acquisition equipment along with initial laboratory setup of the system prior to application in the field. Once the equipment was assembled and lab validated, it was installed on the structure (see attached Image 3). Periodic field and remote checking of the instrumentation has been performed throughout data collection. This activity is still in-progress due to construction delays.
  • Date Processing and Dissemination: Throughout the deconstruction monitoring the data has and will continue to be checked for data quality and processed as necessary. In addition, the data will be disseminated along with clear and comprehensive metadata.
  • Data Interpretation and Numerical Simulation Studies: Initially direct data (model-free) evaluation of the measurements has and will continue to be performed along with drawing conclusions. In addition, model-experiment correlation will be conducted using the previously created FE model for additional understanding of the locked-in internal force variation, redundancy, and simulation capabilities.  
  • Results: One of the main findings thus far is due to the concrete deck and roadway stringer removal. Internal force variation from this partial deconstruction has been recorded and evaluated. From this data we have been able to identify the original construction sequence of the steel truss and the partial distribution of dead load. In short, the construction sequence was determined by the sign of the force release in each of the truss members. The release in force indicates whether the member was in tension or compression in the constructed state. The attached Image 4 shows the force released in the truss cross-section #2 (middle of the end span). This cross-section is in the 3rd span of a three-span continuous truss. Many older truss bridges were constructed as simple spans and then connected together so they acted continuous under live load. That was not the case for the bridge studied in this project. The center span was constructed and then the outer spans were cantilevered out from the center. This could not have been determined with any current technique presently available and illustrates the importance of further research in the area of internal forc...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Force measurements have and are currently being collected during deconstruction of a steel truss bridge. This effort is allowing the research team to advance our understanding with regard to locked-in internal force variation within constructed structural systems. In large-scale structural systems these locked-in forces are substantially greater than typical forces due to service loads. However, the majority of the experimental research has focused on structural behavior due to service loads, as well as extreme events. This is partly due to the fact that experimental techniques are limited with regard to measurement of locked-in internal forces. As a result, numerical models are assumed to accurately capture these forces simply because no other information is available. At the present time, reliable measurement of total locked-in forces can only be measured through construction monitoring or localized nondestructive evaluation techniques. Each approach has merit and provides important information. Deconstruction monitoring is the methodology utilized in this study to further the knowledge base in this research area. Thus far, the primary outcomes of the project include: Experiment Design: A finite element (FE) model was constructed based on the existing data (see attached Image 1). Sensitivity studies were performed for refinement of the experiment design to ensure meaningful data was obtained from the field measurements. An instrumentation plan was developed that included 48 strain gages and 12 data acquisition systems (see attached Image 2). Data Collection: This effort included design and procurement of all necessary sensors and data acquisition equipment along with initial laboratory setup of the system prior to application in the field. Once the equipment was assembled and lab validated, it was installed on the structure (see attached Image 3). Periodic field and remote checking of the instrumentation has been performed throughout data collection. This activity is still in-progress due to construction delays. Date Processing and Dissemination: Throughout the deconstruction monitoring the data has and will continue to be checked for data quality and processed as necessary. In addition, the data will be disseminated along with clear and comprehensive metadata. Data Interpretation and Numerical Simulation Studies: Initially direct data (model-free) evaluation of the measurements has and will continue to be performed along with drawing conclusions. In addition, model-experiment correlation will be conducted using the previously created FE model for additional understanding of the locked-in internal force variation, redundancy, and simulation capabilities. Results: One of the main findings thus far is due to the concrete deck and roadway stringer removal. Internal force variation from this partial deconstruction has been recorded and evaluated. From this data we have been able to identify the original construction sequence of the steel truss and the partial distribution of dead load. In short, the construction sequence was determined by the sign of the force release in each of the truss members. The release in force indicates whether the member was in tension or compression in the constructed state. The attached Image 4 shows the force released in the truss cross-section #2 (middle of the end span). This cross-section is in the 3rd span of a three-span continuous truss. Many older truss bridges were constructed as simple spans and then connected together so they acted continuous under live load. That was not the case for the bridge studied in this project. The center span was constructed and then the outer spans were cantilevered out from the center. This could not have been determined with any current technique presently available and illustrates the importance of further research in the area of internal force measurement. Note the research findings are being documented through a graduate student thesis. The results will ...
